physDesc.p: This letter is four pages long (seq. 10-13). It is typed on something like notebook paper with hole punches in it on all four pages. The words "John Gould Fletcher" are written in pencil across the top of the first page. Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I have got a lot of letters to write; but as you most thoughtfully and kindly say, I am so busy that it is almost impossible to write.

Your poem "Chicago" was forwarded to me in New York, and I meant to sit right down and tell you how much I liked it, and how exceedingly swirling and windy I think it is. Where in the Devil you got such a nice expression as "smoky-blue pipes" from I wish I knew, and I would go and pick some like it. I have not time to go through it in detail and tell you all I think of it; I will reserve that until we meet.

I am rehearsing our operettas for eight hours a day; and before the rehearsals begin and after they end, I am too done to sit down and write. I am dictating this letter now while I am dressing, because I cannot let any longer time elapse before sending you a word, and also because I have been having a terrible time about the title of the Anthology.

I won’t tell you all my tribulations; it would take too long. Suffice it to say that Ferris Greenslet was very much averse to changing the name, feeling that Imagiste had come to mean a certain kind of poetry, and had therefore a certain mercantile value. He accepted us under that title and advertised us so and, although he was very nice about it, he was a good deal upset by the proposal of a change. I, too, felt that a change was the greatest mistake in the world. Even if Ezra had invented the name, it is we who have given the name value; for all the good work that Ezra has done since he announced himself an Imagiste could be crowded in a couple of pages, if it took as much room as that. I did not like to be downed either; and if Ezra published me without my permission in the first Anthology as an Imagiste, I have a great objection to backing down at his bidding when he decides that he does not want me to be one.

I sent a cable to Richard, which it hurt me very much to do, explaining this as well as I could. And to-day comes a letter from him, enclosing one from Flint. Flint’s letter says that he remembers that Ezra did not invent the name "Imagiste," that it started in their talks at a little club where they used to meet, called "The Poets’ Club," of which Hulme was the founder, when they were always talking about the image. He adds: "Of course, at the back of my head I have known this all the time, but I never took the thing seriously. However, if Ezra is going to make it a part of his strategie litteraire to our hurt, then I think that it and he should be put in their place." He also suggests putting this in a preface. But I know that a fighting preface is a mistake. The fighting should come afterwards, in the "Egoist" and elsewhere, if we need to fight.

Richard writes as follows: "I enclose a note from Flint to me which came five minutes after your wires. That letter and our great desire to play square all round influenced us to say that, if you and Houghton, Mifflin consider the Imagiste title absolutely necessary, why we will acquiesce. You know how much we want the Anthology. And though we really do not want the Imagiste title, we won't stand in the way of its coming out. So go ahead in the name of God and St. George." Under these circumstances, Mr. Greenslet and I have decided that really it is much easier to keep the name "Imagiste."

At first we thought of calling it "Quintessentialist;" but that is too long, and I am sure the public is tired of "ists" and we had better hold to what we have got. If Ezra turns stuffy, we will burst into print and tell something closely approaching the whole story. As it is, I really think that to allow Ezra to take us up to ornament his career with when he chooses and drop us when he thinks we sparkle a little too brightly is a very foolish position for us to be in. Also our work is so much superior to his, and so much better than any work which he can get his new satellites to do, that I think whether or not they call themselves Imagistes will matter not at all. The public will soon be able to tell the false from the true. Therefore, I am taking the liberty of going ahead on this plan with Flint's and Richard's and Hilda's consent, in spite of what you wrote to me, as I feel sure that, if you were here and I could explain everything to you in detail by word of mouth, you would agree with me that it was the best thing to do; in fact I am assuming so much on my friendship as to take your permission for granted.

It has not been any easy business running this Anthology, and I feel quite sure that, had I known what it meant, I should never have proposed it. But I do not want to back down now. I only want you to help me fight Ezra if necessary, and help us make the name "Imagiste" which was forced upon us against our will into something so worth while that its connection with Ezra and his littlenesses will be forgotten.

It is a horrible thing, working with so many people, so many miles apart. I want to please everybody; and I want to be fair to the publisher, who has been awfully square with us and most patient over all these suggested changes; and I hope that in the end what I do will please you too. At any rate, the book is Imagiste now, and Imagiste it must remain; and with Flint’s and Richard’s agreeing, I am sure you won’t be the one to stand out.

We cannot get a poem of Hueffer’s in, as Richard does not like to ask him; and there is no time now to write, as the book has gone to press, I believe. Otherwise it will come out after the others of the series, which would be a great mistake. I do hope you are coming here soon; I want very much to see you. It is always more satisfactory to talk than to write, particularly when you are rehearsing eight hours a day. I wish you could be here for our operettas next week; but I fear it is too late for that now, and I don’t know whether you would enjoy them very much.

Croly of "The New Republic" was very much interested in your Indian poem and took the whole thing to consider, saying that he would let me know if he could get it to pass the other editors; and whether he will take it all or in part, I do not know. I left it with him and have heard nothing more. I will you know as soon as I do. Forgive haste, but I wanted to put you au courant as soon as possible.
